newsitem.title: USA: Avant! moves to disqualify prosecutor.
newsitem.headline: Avant! moves to disqualify prosecutor.

text.p: Avant! Corp, whose executives face felony charges of trade secret theft, filed a court motion on Monday to disqualify the prosecutor from handling the lawsuit, citing conflict of interest and unfair access to evidence.

Avant! said in a motion filed in a San Jose, California, court that the Santa Clara district attorney based his criminal investigation on experts paid for by Cadence Design System Inc, a software company that competes against Avant!.

Avant! also said that because Cadence executives knew of the district attorney's investigation, they allegedly profited by selling Avant!'s stock "short," just before the prosecutor raided Avant! for evidence.
In a short sale, investors profit from a stock's decline by borrowing shares, selling them immediately and replacing the stock once the share price drops.
Officials in the Santa Clara district attorney's office could not be reached immediately.
For the past three years, Avant! has been fighting a civil lawsuit filed by Cadence. Both companies write software that help engineers design computer chips.
Cadence alleges that Avant! executives stole a computer programming code from Cadence and based their key products on Cadence technology.
In April, the Santa Clara district attorney increased the pressure on Avant! and its executives by filing criminal charges alleging trade secret theft.
Avant! executives have denied any wrongdoing.
In its motion, Avant! said the district attorney, in an unusual move, has refused to provide Avant! with access to evidence until after the preliminary hearing.
Cadence executives could not be reached immediately for comment.
